basics.name: Jaleh Mahdavi, PhD
basics.label: Data Scientist
basics.summary: Data Scientist with a PhD in Computer Engineering and 10+ years of experience leveraging Machine Learning, NLP, and Social Computing to explore and address real-world social and organizational problems.

work.name: Home
work.summary: Took maternity leave to care for my newborn; now re-engaging with full-time work and ready to bring fresh energy and perspective to new opportunities.

work.name: Toronto Metropolitan University, Toronto
work.summary: Uniquely sponsored by Royal Bank of Canada to bridge academic research and real-world application in people analytics, balancing full-time work at the bank with doctoral research in partnership with academia.
highlights: Collaborated with industry partners to conduct workforce analytics projects focused on skills evolution and well-being.
Applied machine learning, natural language processing, and statistical techniques to model the discussed topics on social media
Developed predictive models for time series forecasting purposes.
Presented research insights and findings to RBC leadership and key stakeholders and published in peer-reviewed journals.

work.name: Toronto Metropolitan University, Toronto
highlights: Led people analytics research projects in collaboration with the University of Toronto.
Supervised graduate and undergraduate students in workforce-related data projects.

work.name: Microsoft, Office of Applied Research, Toronto
highlights: Based on my expertise in the Future of Work domain, business requirements, and existing user research, I introduced and designed a new feature for Microsoft Loop to bridge the gap between research and products. This feature enables the workforce to complete micro-tasks when mobile or during low focus/attention.

Worked with the Human Understanding and Empathy team to detect the well-being of employees across demographics on survey data using qualitative and quantitative methods. The results of these two projects help employers obtain data-driven insights from their workforce and tune their strategies accordingly.

work.name: Royal Bank of Canada, Toronto
highlights: Partnered with HR business leaders to uncover analytical needs and deliver customized, data-driven solutions.
Developed large-scale datasets by consolidating data from RBC HR platform, employee surveys, Social Media, and external labor market sources.

Developed a skill retrieval engine and identified emerging skills by time series analysis and NLP techniques to build and attract future skills to ensure that RBC and the people remain relevant and competitive into the future.
Developed an employee attrition and scoring model to detect the probability of employee attrition using classical machine learning algorithms and deep learning techniques.

work.name: Serenova, Fredericton
highlights: Accelerated the process of testing by developing automated test scripts
Analyzed bugs and defects during the testing process
Documented test results for the software development team

education.institution: Azad University of Tehran, North Branch

volunteer.summary: Lead organizer for the New York City branch of the People's Climate March, the largest climate march in history.
highlights: Awarded 'Climate Hero' award by Greenpeace for my efforts organizing the march.
Men of the year 2014 by Time magazine

awards.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
awards.summary: The Nobel Prizes are five separate prizes that, according to Alfred Nobel's will of 1895, are awarded to 'those who, during the preceding year, have conferred the greatest benefit to humankind.'

publications.name: Zur Elektrody/namik bewegter Körper
publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

publications.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

publications.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).

projects.name: Quantum Computing
projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
